Text saved: Society, not nature, often tells girls that they should prefer arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to boys. This idea is reinforced by the missing female role models in science‑related jobs. Cartoons and stories usually show the crazy scientist, the genius inventor, or the adventurous astronaut as a man. They also present scientists as geeky, having poor social skills, or working alone and detached from the rest of the world. These false stereotypes may prevent girls from identifying with scientists and seeing science as an attractive career path. If more positive female role models were shown, girls would gain more confidence and a stronger sense of belonging in those subjects.

Text saved: Society, not nature, often tells girls that they should prefer arts and leave maths and physics to boys. This idea is made stronger by the lack of female role models in science jobs. Cartoons and stories usually show the crazy scientist, the very smart inventor, or the adventurous astronaut as a man. They also show scientists as geeky, with poor social skills, or working alone and away from other people. These false ideas may stop girls from seeing scientists as people like them and from thinking science is a good career. If girls saw more positive female role models in science, they would feel more confidence and a strong feeling of belonging in those subjects.
